title: Google Map - Usage Examples
description: Embed Google Maps with single or multiple locations, custom pins, styled maps, overlay content. Perfect for contact pages, store locators, event venues.

examples.name: Single Location (Business/Office)
examples.description: Simple map showing one business location with custom pin and default controls
examples.visualDescription: 400px height roadmap centered on business location (New York), custom pin icon, zoom level 14, all standard controls enabled (zoom, street view, etc.)
examples.useCase: Contact pages, office location, single business address, about pages
notes: latitude/longitude provides precise location (40.7580, -73.9855 = Times Square NYC)
latOrAddr='latitude' means use lat/long coordinates (not address geocoding)
Zoom: 1=world, 5=continent, 10=city, 15=streets, 20=buildings (14 is good for business)
gmapType='roadmap' is standard street map view
Custom pinIcon replaces default red Google marker (thumbnail = 150x150px)
All control toggles set to true (user can zoom, pan, switch views, etc.)
Responsive mapHeight: 400px desktop, 350px tablet, 300px mobile

examples.name: Multiple Locations (Store Locator)
examples.description: Map showing 3 store locations across USA with default pins
examples.visualDescription: 500px height map showing 3 cities (LA, NYC, Chicago), zoomed out to show all locations (zoom 4), standard red pins, no custom styling
examples.useCase: Store locators, multi-location businesses, branch maps, franchise locations, service areas
notes: Multiple locationPoint items create multiple pins on same map
_key must be unique for each location (0, 1, 2...)
Zoom=4 shows entire USA (good for nationwide locations)
Empty pinIcon.url uses default Google red marker
address field is for reference only when latOrAddr='latitude' (coordinates used for positioning)
Map auto-centers to show all pins when multiple locations present
Add more locations by adding items to locationPoint array

examples.name: Address-Based Geocoding (No Coordinates)
examples.description: Map location using street address instead of latitude/longitude
examples.visualDescription: 350px height map showing Google HQ in Mountain View CA, located via address geocoding, standard controls
examples.useCase: When you only have street address (no coordinates), event venues, contact pages, address-based locations
notes: CRITICAL: latOrAddr='address' switches from coordinates to geocoding
addr field contains full street address for geocoding
Google Maps API converts address to lat/long automatically (requires API key)
latitude and longitude fields can be empty when using address mode
Address should be specific: street number, street name, city, state, zip
Geocoding may fail for vague addresses ('downtown' won't work, '123 Main St, City, State' will)
Zoom=15 good for street-level view of specific address

examples.name: Custom Styled Map (Monochrome)
examples.description: Grayscale styled map with custom appearance (no standard colors)
examples.visualDescription: Monochrome black and white map, custom style-3 applied, satellite view toggle disabled, artistic appearance for modern design
examples.useCase: Modern minimalist designs, branded maps, artistic presentations, portfolio sites
notes: customStyleTgl=true enables predefined custom map styling
customStyle options: 'style-1', 'style-2', 'style-3', etc. (check plugin for available styles)
Custom styles change colors, labels, road appearance (e.g., monochrome, retro, night mode)
mapTypeCtrl=false hides map type switcher (user can't change to satellite)
streetViewCtrl=false hides street view pegman icon
Disabling controls creates cleaner appearance for design-focused sites
Custom styles override gmapType colors but roadmap/satellite structure remains

examples.name: Overlay Content (Info Box)
examples.description: Map with toggleable overlay info box showing title and description
examples.visualDescription: Map with white semi-transparent overlay box in corner, 'Our Locations' title in dark gray, description text, toggle switch to show/hide content

attributes.title: Visit Our Paris Office
attributes.description: Located in the heart of the city. Open Monday-Friday, 9AM-6PM. Free parking available.

examples.useCase: Contact pages with additional info, event venues with details, business hours display, location instructions
notes: contentTgl=true enables overlay content box on map
title and description appear in overlay box (supports HTML)
contentBG with rgba(255,255,255,0.95) creates semi-transparent white background
titleTypo and descTypo control text styling (font size, weight, etc.)
titleColor and descColor set text colors
toggleColor and tglActiveClr style the toggle switch (show/hide content)
Overlay box is toggleable (user can show/hide with switch icon)
Keep description concise (2-3 sentences max for readability in overlay)

examples.name: Satellite View (Aerial Photography)
examples.description: Satellite imagery map with aerial photos instead of drawn map
examples.visualDescription: Satellite photo view showing aerial imagery of Grand Canyon, zoom 18 for close-up detail, hybrid labels optional
examples.useCase: Property showcases, real estate, outdoor venues, geographic features, aerial views
notes: gmapType='satellite' shows aerial photography instead of drawn roads
gmapType options: 'roadmap' (default), 'satellite' (aerial photos), 'hybrid' (satellite + labels), 'terrain' (topographic)
Zoom=18 provides very close aerial view (good for property details)
Satellite view best for showcasing buildings, landscapes, property boundaries
Hybrid combines satellite imagery with road/label overlays
Not all areas have high-resolution satellite imagery (zoom out if pixelated)

examples.name: Terrain View (Topographic)
examples.description: Terrain map showing elevation and topographic features
examples.visualDescription: Terrain map of Rocky Mountains showing elevation shading, mountain ranges, valleys, topographic relief
examples.useCase: Outdoor events, hiking trails, geographic education, mountainous regions, topographic references
notes: gmapType='terrain' shows elevation and landforms (mountains, valleys)
Terrain view uses shading to indicate elevation changes
Best for mountainous or hilly regions (flat areas show little terrain detail)
Zoom 6-10 good for regional terrain overview
Combine with lower zoom to show larger geographic context

examples.name: Minimal Map (Controls Disabled)
examples.description: Static-looking map with most user controls disabled for clean presentation
examples.visualDescription: Clean map with no scroll zoom, no street view, no drag, minimal UI, just displays location without interaction clutter
examples.useCase: Simple location display, minimal designs, when interaction not needed, print-friendly maps
notes: scrollWheel=false prevents accidental zoom on page scroll
Draggable=false prevents map panning (static position)
panCtrl=false hides pan control arrows
mapTypeCtrl=false hides map/satellite switcher
scaleCtrl=false hides scale bar
fullScreenCtrl=false hides fullscreen button
streetViewCtrl=false hides pegman icon
zoomCtrl=true kept enabled for basic zoom in/out
Use when map is for reference only (not interactive exploration)
Prevents user frustration from accidentally interacting with map while scrolling page

coordinates.bestFor: Precise locations, known coordinates, multiple pins, performance (no geocoding API call)
coordinates.notes: Fastest method, no dependency on geocoding API

address.description: Use street address for geocoding (Google converts to coordinates)
address.bestFor: When only street address available, user-friendly address display
address.notes: Requires Google Geocoding API, may have daily quota limits, address must be specific

mapTypes.roadmap: Standard street map with roads and labels (default)
mapTypes.terrain: Topographic view showing elevation and landforms

controlToggles.scrollWheel: Mouse wheel zoom (true=enabled, false=prevents accidental zoom on page scroll)

customStyling.availableStyles: style-1, style-2, style-3, etc. (check plugin documentation for specific style previews)
customStyling.notes: Custom styles change map colors, labels, road appearance for branded/artistic looks

overlayContent.description: Add toggleable info box on map
overlayContent.bestFor: Contact pages, location details, business hours, directions
overlayContent.notes: Semi-transparent background (rgba) allows map to show through

validationRules.locationPoint: Required, array with at least 1 location, each item needs _key
validationRules._key: Required for each locationPoint item, must be unique, use sequential: '0', '1', '2'...
validationRules.latitude: Required when latOrAddr='latitude', decimal degrees format (e.g., 40.7580)
validationRules.longitude: Required when latOrAddr='latitude', decimal degrees format (e.g., -73.9855)
validationRules.addr: Required when latOrAddr='address', full street address with city, state, zip
validationRules.pinIcon: Optional, object with {url, id}, url empty uses default Google marker
validationRules.mapHeight: Required, responsive object {md, sm, xs, unit}, min 200px recommended
validationRules.Zoom: Required, number 1-21 (decimal allowed like 8.5), higher = closer
validationRules.customStyle: Required when customStyleTgl=true, options vary by plugin (style-1, style-2...)
validationRules.contentTgl: Boolean, if true requires title or description
validationRules.Google Maps API Key: CRITICAL: Block requires valid Google Maps JavaScript API key configured in WordPress settings

warnings: CRITICAL: Requires Google Maps JavaScript API key (configure in WordPress admin or plugin settings)
CRITICAL: Google Maps API has usage quotas and billing (may incur costs for high traffic)
CRITICAL: latOrAddr='address' requires Geocoding API enabled (separate from Maps API)
Don't use vague addresses with geocoding ('downtown' won't work, use full street address)
Don't forget unique _key for each locationPoint item (duplicates cause rendering issues)
Zoom too high (20+) may show no imagery (zoom out if map appears blank)
Satellite imagery quality varies by region (urban areas better than rural)
Custom styles may not be compatible with all gmapType values (test combinations)
scrollWheel=true can cause page scroll frustration (users accidentally zoom map while scrolling page)
Multiple locations with high zoom may only show one pin (map can't fit all - lower zoom or use bounds)
Geocoding (latOrAddr='address') is slower than coordinates (API lookup required)
Geocoding may fail for new addresses, international formats, or ambiguous locations
pinIcon with large image slows page load (use optimized 100x100px PNG/WebP)
Overlay content (contentTgl=true) may cover map on mobile (keep description short)
Disabling all controls (Draggable=false, zoomCtrl=false, etc.) makes map unusable for exploration
commonMistakes: Forgetting to configure Google Maps API key (map shows 'For development purposes only' watermark or doesn't load)
Using latOrAddr='latitude' without providing latitude/longitude values
Using latOrAddr='address' without Geocoding API enabled (map doesn't center correctly)
Providing incomplete addresses ('123 Main St' without city/state - geocoding fails)
Using duplicate _key values in locationPoint array (causes pin conflicts)
Setting Zoom too high (21) for rural areas (satellite imagery may be blank)
Setting Zoom too low (1-3) for single location (map too zoomed out to see pin)
Enabling customStyleTgl without setting customStyle value (no style applied)
Setting contentTgl=true without providing title or description (empty overlay box)
Not optimizing pinIcon images (large images slow page load)
Forgetting to set mapHeight (map collapses to 0 height)
Using scrollWheel=true on pages with lots of scrolling (users accidentally zoom map)
Mixing latitude/longitude with addr field when latOrAddr='latitude' (addr ignored, confusion)
Not testing on mobile (overlay content may be unreadable, controls too small)
Using invalid gmapType value (must be exactly 'roadmap', 'satellite', 'hybrid', or 'terrain')
bestPractices: Always use unique _key values: '0', '1', '2', '3'... for locationPoint items
For single precise location: use latOrAddr='latitude' with exact coordinates (fastest, most reliable)
For user-friendly address: use latOrAddr='address' with full street address (easier for content editors)
Set responsive mapHeight: {md: 400-500px, sm: 350px, xs: 300px} for good visibility
For single location: Zoom=12-15 (street-level detail)
For multiple locations: Zoom=4-8 (fit all pins in view, map auto-adjusts center)
For minimal designs: disable streetViewCtrl, mapTypeCtrl, scaleCtrl, fullScreenCtrl
For static reference maps: scrollWheel=false, Draggable=false (prevents accidental interaction)
For interactive exploration: keep all controls enabled (default settings)
Optimize custom pin icons: 100x100px PNG or WebP, compressed, use pinIconSize='thumbnail'
Use gmapType='roadmap' for general locations, 'satellite' for property/buildings, 'terrain' for hiking/outdoor
For overlay content: semi-transparent background (rgba 0.9-0.95 opacity) so map shows through
Keep overlay description to 2-3 sentences max (avoid scrolling inside overlay)
Use customStyleTgl for branded maps (match site color scheme with style-1/style-2/style-3)
Test on mobile: ensure controls are accessible, text is readable, height appropriate
For store locators: use multiple locationPoint items, Zoom=4-6, no overlay content (cleaner)
For contact pages: use single location, contentTgl=true with business hours/address in overlay
Test API key limits: monitor Google Cloud Console for usage (avoid unexpected billing)
Cache map tiles when possible (WordPress caching plugins help)
Consider accessibility: provide text address below map for screen reader users
accessibilityNotes: Provide text address below or near map (screen readers can't read visual maps)
Use descriptive title in overlay content (e.g., 'Main Office Location' not 'Map')
Ensure overlay text has sufficient contrast (WCAG AA: 4.5:1 for body text)
Make overlay toggleable (contentTgl allows users to hide if blocking content)
Avoid relying solely on map for critical location info (provide text address separately)
Test keyboard navigation (Google Maps has built-in keyboard support, ensure not disabled)
Provide alternative directions link (e.g., link to Google Maps directions page)
Use semantic HTML around map (heading above map, address below)
Don't auto-play animations or transitions (Google Maps default behavior is user-controlled)
Ensure touch targets are at least 44x44px (Google's default controls meet this, but verify on mobile)
Test with screen readers (NVDA, JAWS, VoiceOver) - map should announce as interactive region
Consider adding aria-label to map container describing purpose (e.g., 'Office location map')
performanceConsiderations: Limit locationPoint items to 10-20 max (many pins slow map rendering)
Optimize pinIcon images: 100x100px max, WebP format, compressed (TinyPNG)
Use pinIconSize='thumbnail' (150x150px) not 'full' (original size may be huge)
For many locations (20+): consider clustering plugins or separate location pages
Lazy load map (load only when user scrolls near it, reduces initial page load)
Use latOrAddr='latitude' instead of 'address' when possible (no geocoding API call = faster)
Cache geocoding results server-side if using addresses (avoid repeated API calls)
Monitor Google Maps API usage (excessive calls incur costs, optimize with caching)
Minimize map height on mobile (300px vs 500px desktop - less data to render)
Disable unused controls to reduce UI complexity (mapTypeCtrl, scaleCtrl if not needed)
Avoid multiple Google Maps on same page (each map loads full API, use single map with multiple pins instead)
Use customStyleTgl sparingly (custom styles add rendering overhead)
Test on slow 3G connection (Chrome DevTools throttling) - map tiles may load slowly
Consider static map image for print/email (Google Static Maps API for non-interactive use)
Defer Google Maps API script loading (load after critical page content)
Use intersection observer for lazy loading (only load map when visible in viewport)

googleMapsApiKey.description: How to get and configure Google Maps API key (REQUIRED for this block to work)
steps: 1. Go to Google Cloud Console: https://console.cloud.google.com/
2. Create new project or select existing project
4. Enable 'Geocoding API' if using latOrAddr='address' (for address lookups)
5. Go to Credentials section and create API key
- Application restrictions: HTTP referrers (your website domain)
- API restrictions: Maps JavaScript API, Geocoding API
8. In WordPress admin, go to plugin settings (TheP Plus > Google Maps or similar)
9. Paste API key in 'Google Maps API Key' field
10. Save settings and test map block
billing: Google Maps API requires billing account (credit card) even for free tier
Free tier: $200 monthly credit (covers ~28,000 map loads)
Pricing: ~$7 per 1,000 map loads after free credit
Monitor usage in Google Cloud Console to avoid unexpected charges
troubleshooting: Map shows 'For development purposes only' → API key not configured or invalid
Map shows gray box → API key restrictions too strict (check HTTP referrers)
Map doesn't center on address → Geocoding API not enabled
Map shows error 'This page can't load Google Maps correctly' → Billing not enabled on API project
Pin doesn't appear → Check latitude/longitude values, ensure _key is unique

relatedBlocks: tpgb/tp-heading - Heading above map (section title like 'Find Us')
tpgb/tp-pro-paragraph - Text below map (address, directions, business hours)
tpgb/tp-container - Wrapper container for map section with background/padding
tpgb/tp-button - CTA button near map ('Get Directions', 'Contact Us')
tpgb/tp-social-feed - Social media feed showing location tags (complement to map)
